text: Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So the first is, which is the most promising, is that the cancer goes into remission. That’s about one-third of patients. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And then in about one-third of patients, the cancer neither grows nor shrinks. So it basically stabilizes. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And that stabilization typically lasts anywhere from six to twelve months. So it’s not permanent. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: It’s just for a period of time. And then the last third, the cancer continued to grow at roughly the same pace that it was growing before. Patient: How so? Doctor: So the therapy did not appear to be effective. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: But it also did not appear to accelerate or worsen the cancer. Patient: Oh okay.

Doctor: But it also did not appear to accelerate or worsen the cancer. Patient: Oh okay.

text: Family Member: How soon can he get into the trial? Doctor: So what usually happens in general for clinical trials is that if you're interested in clinical trials, what I'll do is I'll contact the research nurse, and I'll say, you know, “Mr. H____ is interested in this clinical trial let's do it” because we have to make sure that your insurance allows you to be in clinical trials, and we have to confirm your eligibility and like for this, the MAP study- Family Member: Mhm. Doctor: -we would have you sign consent to do the testing to see the genotype first. So usually the time, from like, we're talking about it, and you are thinking about doing it to like, actually starting is a couple weeks. Family Member: Two to four. Doctor: It's always like, yeah, like, almost always within a month. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So, you know, probably, I mean, both of these probably two weeks. Patient: Did you get the results I emailed you. The DNA. Doctor: Yes. So, I got back the germline genetics testing. So this that this testing, well, do you remember? Tell me what you remember about that testing. The saliva testing that you did Patient: He was going to try to figure out um.. if this was hereditary or something. Doctor: Right, exactly. So that was negative for the, for the cancer causing gene. So that was negative. That is a different that's different than this.

text: Family Member: Not the sixteenth? Doctor: I’ll e-mail him, but you can also tell him at the next appointment. Patient: I will. Doctor: You think it’s best – does he think it’s a good idea? He and I do this all the time. We, we transition after he’s finished with the radiation part. Because, unless - I mean, he’s not going away. We might need him again. Family Member: Right. Doctor: Down the road maybe. I don’t know. I hope not. text: Family Member: -so he would continue to take the Xtandi along with the chemo? Doctor: No, we would stop it. Family Member: Okay, then I was gonna say I kind of misinterpreted that. Doctor: Yeah, we just stop the Xtandi. Patient: Continue it until I start the trial? Doctor: Nope, you just stop it. It's not doing its thing. If you want to do the trial, or if you're okay with chemo as the next step. But either way Xtandi’s not doing it. So we need to bail out of that. It's just giving you side effects with no gain. Family Member: So how soon would you try to start the new treatment Doctor: I think there's like a good at least two to three week washout you know we got to let that one get out of your system. text: Family Member: Being a pain in the ass. Patient: He wants more custody of the kids. So, she has her own mess. Doctor: I get it. Well, what we would be doing is we’d be seeing a lot of you. So, again, some of those visits she – you know, hopefully, the court stuff is better that she can come down with you. Patient: Uh, huh. Doctor: Um. So, does that make sense to try that and go that route? I mean, or is it really you want to think about it more – uh, step back and again talk to your doctor about the chemo again? Do you want to get his opinion or her opinion about the trial? Um. Patient: I think the, the trial’s a little more targeted. The chemo is more general. Doctor: Ehhhh -- Well it’s – uh. The immunotherapy’s targeted to the immune system, but it’s not targeted to your cancer. Again, it, too, is like chemotherapy, praying and hoping that it’s gonna attack your cancer. Patient: Uh-huh. Okay. Doctor: It definitely has less side effects than chemotherapy. It just has more risk because if it attacks you, then you can get into trouble faster. Patient: My hair will fall out again? Doctor: Nope. (Pause) Patient: Okay will it get curlier?

text: Patient: I’m, I’m interested in. Doctor: Let me, uh- Patient: And plus it also, it, its information that could be useful to maybe help other people. You know? Doctor: Yeah. Let me find out about the, the biopsy requirements today, uh. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I know we have some trials that if you have bone, they do not, you can’t be on the trial, because they just don’t get the tissue. Patient: Right. Doctor: So they don’t want to, uh, subject you to, you know, have a needle stuck in your bone if it’s not going to be helpful. Patient: Right. Doctor: And so, but the trial requires the tissue, because they’re trying to study how the new drug affects the tissue in some way. So let me, let me look into that, uh, to see if any of the trials allow bone only. The only trials we have for hormonal treatment are with Xtandi right now, uh, not with the other drug. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So, if it looks like you can’t, if it looks like you would fit on the trial, we can talk about them more. If, if it looks like the bone thing is going to eliminate that-

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
